conclusion: To determine if thermal motion becomes more intense from B to C, analyze the Stirling cycle in the p-V diagram.
Stirling cycle consists of A→B (isothermal expansion), B→C (adiabatic compression), C→D (isothermal compression), D→A (adiabatic expansion).
In an isothermal process, temperature remains constant.
In an adiabatic process, there is no heat exchange with surroundings.
During A→B, temperature remains constant; thermal motion does not change.
During B→C, volume decreases, pressure and temperature increase; thermal motion becomes more intense.
During C→D, temperature remains constant; thermal motion does not change.
During D→A, volume increases, pressure and temperature decrease; thermal motion decreases.
Thermal motion is related to temperature; it becomes more intense during B→C.
Final Answer: Yes, thermal motion becomes more intense from B to C.
